awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: LEARNing To Build STEM Research Communities- A Proposal to Strengthen, Expand, and Disseminate a Successful Retention Model
awd_abstract_narration:
A previous NSF-supported project has resulted in high retention and improved GPA for STEM majors at the University of Central Florida.  In an effort to expand on this work the institution has partnered with investigators at the University of NC-Wilmington (a primarily undergraduate, public institution) and Florida Atlantic University (a research-1, public institution) to study the ways in which a community built on disciplinary research will affect the retention of first-year students in STEM.  The participants will live together in a learning community, take courses together, and work as research apprentices in faculty laboratories.  This model, which has been shown to be particularly effective with students from underrepresented groups and first generation majors, will be adapted to include strategies for retaining transfer students through to graduation as well.

The core elements of the UCF model are the development of an academic research community that provides students with hands-on learning opportunities, access to faculty and trained graduate student and peer research mentors, and integration into student life through a wide variety of academic, social, and service activities.  This project will address three research questions that are central to the national goal of increasing the number of high quality STEM graduates who go on to graduate school and into the workforce: (a) Can the UCF research community model be adapted successfully to accommodate a transfer student population? (b) What factors within a STEM research community influence transfer student success and impact transfer student retention? And (c) To what extent is the retention success of a current model replicable at other, public institutions?  Formative and summative assessment will focus on the efficacy of the model on student retention and success in STEM for the different student populations (first-year and transfer) and at different institutions.  The plan will use a mixed-method approach to assess the effectiveness of the proposed educational tools and educational content in fulfilling the desired learning outcomes, from both educators' and participants' perspectives.  Student retention and GPA will be compared to matched cohorts.  The findings from this project will be presented at state and national meetings such as the Florida Statewide Symposium on Engagement in Undergraduate Research and the Council on Undergraduate Research biennial conference.  Results will also be submitted to the Journal of College Science Teaching.

inst.inst_name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES

por.por_cntn:
The Learning Environment and Academic Research Network (L.E.A.R.N.) model was developed at the University of Central Florida (UCF) with funding from a previous NSF grant to improve the retention and graduation rates of first-year students in the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines. Our strategy in this project has students live together in a learning community, take courses together, and work as research apprentices in faculty laboratories. Results from the first L.E.A.R.N. cohorts show improved retention rates, graduation rates, and critical thinking skills.  To determine if the success of this program at UCF is more broadly applicable, faculty at UCF partnered with faculty at Florida Atlantic University (FAU) and Western Carolina University (WCU) in a 5-year study. Building upon the success achieved by the UCF first-time-in-college (FTIC) students (F-L.E.A.R.N. for first-year students), we adapted this model for use at both FAU and WCU.  In addition,  F-L.E.A.R.N. was modified further to accommodate incoming upper-division Associate in Arts (AA) transfer STEM students (T-L.E.A.R.N. for transfer students) at UCF and we extended the T-L.E.A.R.N. model to FAU and WCU to form the L.E.A.R.N. Consortium. 

The two research questions our proposal put forth included:  (1) To what extent can we positively impact transfer student STEM retention and success by adopting a successful STEM FTIC community-cohort undergraduate research model to an AA transfer student population at three institutions, and (2) To what extent can we replicate the retention success of an FTIC community-cohort undergraduate research program at two other institutions? 

 

To answer these questions, we implemented the following goals: (a) Adapt the current L.E.A.R.N. model to a transfer student population (T-L.E.A.R.N.) at UCF, FAU, and WCU, (b) Implement the L.E.A.R.N. model for FTIC students (F-L.E.A.R.N.) to WCU and FAU, (c) Assess the impacts of the L.E.A.R.N. consortium on student retention and success in STEM for different student populations and at different institutions, and (d) Disseminate the L.E.A.R.N. model to expand the L.E.A.R.N. consortium.  The new model was developed by adapting the UCF successful retention model for 1st-year students that centers around three main pillars: (1) academics/research, (2) mentoring, and (3) community building (Meeroff et al. 2020). 

Our overall findings from the three institutions indicate that T-LEARN students’ involvement in research during their 1st year was the most significant factor within the T-LEARN program that contributed to their academic success (Chamely et al. 2021). Additionally, the majority of these students continued to do research with the same LEARN program faculty mentor 1 year (and sometimes longer)  after the program ended. The consortium continues to explore how F-LEARN adaptation has impacted students on the WCU and FAU campuses (Kwochka et al. In Prep). 

 The F-LEARN at UCF (F-LEARN@ucf) completed its 11th year (as this grant was built off of this program). We continue to monitor the long-term success of the program and this second grant helped us holistically learn about the long-term impact. Enough students have matriculated through the UCF undergraduate system that we can now draw some conclusions for the data collected. Graduation rates are significantly higher for all majors and within STEM. Additionally, we see this same trend for our underrepresented student populations, where we observe the highest STEM graduation rates within the program (Schneider et al. 2021). We also report in Schneider et al (2021) that students are 2.5 times more likely to be involved in research post-LEARN compared to the matched comparison group. 

At UCF, our T-LEARN program has shown similar encouraging results. By fall 2020, 80% of cohort 1 (2016-17) has graduated in a STEM discipline, whereas only 54.7% of the matched comparison group had graduated to date in STEM.  Likewise, 85% of LEARN students have graduated from UCF (some not in STEM) in xx years,   while only 64.2% of the students in the comparison group has graduated from UCF. A similar pattern is emerging with cohort 2 (starting fall 2017): 50% of T-LEARN students graduated in STEM compared to only 21.2% in our comparison group (Schneider et al. In prep).  Finally,  many of these T-LEARN students continue with undergraduate research throughout their time at UCF.

The consortium team worked collaboratively during the entire grant period. WCU and FAU continue to be on a no-cost extension. To date, the team has disseminated the model 17 times at local and national conferences, published three manuscripts, and we have three additional papers in preparation. 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2021
Modified by: Kimberly R Schneider
